reference.author: Winship V

reference.unstructured: The difference between the concepts of deterrence and enforceability is that deterrence is evaluated from the viewpoint of the would-be violator, while enforceability also takes into account the point of view of the beneficiary, which is of equal importance as effective social cooperation aimed at by antitrust rules requires the optimal behaviour of both.

In Reiff's theory, post-violation enforceability is achieved when the amount of punishment and compensation is morally significant in relation to the amount required by justice, which is determined by retributive equivalence. Therefore, strict retributive equivalence is not required as long as the amount imposed through punishment and compensation is morally significant in relation to it. However, due the inherent uncertainty with respect to determining what is a morally significant amount and the economic context of antitrust violations, which makes the calculation of retributive equivalence rather simple, this article argues that post-violation enforceability of antitrust rules be based principally on retributive equivalence.

The relationship between the necessary amount of post-violation sanctions and pre-violation enforceability through the notion of deterrence is complex, but it does not necessarily require that the sanction actually imposed equals what would have been deemed optimal prior to the right's violation.

Monetary punishment and compensation are not the only enforcement means that may be employed to achieve enforceability of a right. There are a number of other means, such as criminal or administrative sanctions, whose utilisation may be merited in specific contexts. Nevertheless, with respect to violations with solely economic effects, it is my view that the imposition of sanctions corresponding to the total amount of damage caused by a violation (retributive equivalence) is an essential component of an enforcement framework.

This article thus does not deal with the goals of antitrust (whether consumer welfare should be its sole goal or if other goals should be pursued as well) or how such goals should fit to the conditions of imperfect competition.

As was also mentioned above, there are a number of other enforcement means of administrative and/or criminal character whose additional utilisation may be desirable in particular contexts. With respect to antitrust violations, which are difficult both to detect and to prove, sanctions other than fines and compensation may be utilised to increase deterrence (such as individual criminal sanctions, which are in place in several EU countries for price fixing violations). While full consideration of such other possible enforcement means exceeds the scope of this article, it is argued that their potential presence (the benefit of which is not disputed) should be additional and not come at the expense of monetary sanctions required to achieve retributive equivalence, which is the minimal necessary requirement to achieve enforceability of antitrust rules.
See, eg H Hovenkamp, The Antitrust Enterprise: Principle and Execution (Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press, 2005), 59.

Theoretically, it could be argued that no private enforcement based on compensation is necessary as long as public enforcement has at its disposal a sufficient amount of available punishment to render antitrust law restraints enforceable in both pre- and post-violation stages. What is a sufficient amount is, however, very problematic to assess. There is no absolutely reliable method of evaluating whether the means at the disposal of public enforcers of EU antitrust law, when assessed in totality, are sufficient to render EU antitrust rules enforceable. So far no such study has been done—to be fair, probably due to the inherent impossibility of carrying out such an assessment with methods of scientifically reasonable accuracy and reliability—with the exception of an external impact study commissioned by the Commission (http://ec.europa.eu/competition/antitrust/actionsdamages/files_white_paper/impact_study.pdf, accessed on 10 June 2009). However, this study, notwithstanding its daunting length of more than 600 pages, stops short of a result that could be deemed reliable and convincing from a scientific method point of view as it relies on a number of assumptions, for example, with respect to the rate of discovery of secret cartels. Therefore, in the absence of convincing proof that public enforcement is sufficient to make EU antitrust rules enforceable in both the pre- and post-violation stages, it may be desirable to insure against its potential insufficiency in either stage by an effective regime of private enforcement built around compensation and injunctive relief.

The oft-cited 9:1 ratio of private v public enforcement actions in the US is an example of such complementarity. However, one should not expect the ratio to be the same in the EU as public enforcement there has much greater capacity (with the European Competition Network including the Commission and NCAs) and is generally more active.
As mentioned above, only exercisable means (means the exercise of which is not hampered by any obstacles) produce the requisite effects.

reference.unstructured: Another possible result may be the setting of wrong incentives for beneficiaries if damages awarded are in excess of what is required by the principle of compensation, eg through punitive damages.

In an ideal situation, all violations would be sanctioned (subject to enforcement action) by exactly the right amount, resulting in the optimal level of enforcement. This is not possible, however, as not all violations are discovered, which gives rise to probability calculations on the part of would-be violators. It is argued that in the antitrust context it is not appropriate to increase sanctions (to make up for the probability discount) as we want to avoid the risk of over-deterrence in situations where the level of enforcement is unstable and uncontrollable (such as when private and public enforcement combines).
See Guidelines on the method of setting fines imposed pursuant to Article 23(2)(a) of Regulation No 1/2003, [2006] OJ C 210/2.

reference.unstructured: Under this mechanism the MDL judicial panel: “i) determines whether civil actions pending in different federal districts involve one or more common questions of fact such that the actions should be transferred to one federal district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings; and ii) selects the judge or judges and court assigned to conduct such proceedings” (http://www.jpml.uscourts.gov/index.html). reference.unstructured: White Paper, s 2.9.

In this respect criticism has been voiced that a Commission initiative aimed at introducing a certain level of uniformity to national substantive and procedural rules relating to damage actions for EC competition rules violations constitutes an unwelcome and unnecessary “back-door harmonization” of national tort laws (See F Marcos and AS Graells, “Towards a European Tort Law? Damages actions for breach of the EC antitrust rules: harmonizing Tort Law through the back door?” (26 October 2007), available at http://ssrn.com/abstract=1028963 (accessed on 10 June 2009)).

Admittedly, requiring competition agencies to calculate the damage caused will require more resources and could possibly negatively affect the number of decisions that can be adopted each year. However, I do not believe that this in itself should be an argument against applying enforcement policy that best promotes the ultimate goal of antitrust—competitive markets for the benefit of consumers. Indeed, calculating the total amount of damage caused by a cartel (essentially the effects of the cartel) could prolong the investigation by a considerable amount of time and doing so is unnecessary due to the wording of Art 81 EC, which prohibits restrictions by effect or object. However, it may be argued that many cartels have relatively little effect on the market and yet are subject to very heavy fines (discount for non-implementation is of no meaningful mitigation in such cases). And while not required under the law, looking at the effects of specific conduct would allow competition authorities to apply the optimal enforcement response for maintaining competitive markets.

reference.volume-title: Postbank v Commission

reference.unstructured: Another potential solution, similar in character to the MDL procedure, was suggested by the Commission in its recently issued Green Paper on the review of Brussels I. There the Commission proposes, with respect to parallel actions, to “provide for a limited extension of the rule in Article 6(1), allowing for a consolidation if the court has jurisdiction over a certain quorum of defendants” (Green Paper on the review of council regulation (EC) No 44/2001 on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters (Brussels, 21 April 2009 COM(2009) 175 final, page 7)).

Suburbs in the City: Reassessing the Location of Nineteenth-Century American Working-Class Suburbs

items.publisher-location: 2455 Teller Road,  Thousand Oaks  California  91320  United States
title: Alley Housing
Rationalität und Moralität

items.abstract: <jats:p>Political boundaries are the criterion scholars use most often to define American suburbs; a problematic approach when applied to the late nineteenth century. Annexation distended the boundaries of nineteenth-century cities so far as to obscure broad swaths of suburban and rural districts within their limits. The absence of a literature about these “suburbs in the city” is problematic, because it encourages historical researchers to consider newly annexed territory as urban equivalents of older city districts. This article argues that under the generally accepted definition of suburb, the condition of nineteenth-century urban overbounding obstructs a full appreciation of the historical breadth, ubiquity, and composition of working-class residence outside the urban core. Analysis of the socioeconomic characteristics of regions with suburban population densities within the 1880 city limits of Cleveland, Ohio; Milwaukee, Wisconsin; Newark, New Jersey; and St. Louis, Missouri, indicate that researchers have underestimated the degree and diversity of blue-collar suburbanization during this period.</jats:p>
title: Suburbs in the City
